title: Between 12 May 2017 and 1 July 2018, will two or more states ratify the Equal Rights Amendment?
preds:
Illinois becomes 37th state to ratify Equal Rights Amendment
Posted May 31, 2018 at 12:15 PM
http://www.fowlertribune.com/zz/news/20180531/illinois-becomes-37th-state-to-ratify-equal-rights-amendment Damn question specifies 2 states.
Barring extreme outlier event, it won't happen this late in the game by the questions deadline
IL just approved it & there are blue or  bluish states out there that could rush a vote: 2% is still very unlikely though
So just waiting on Virginia.  Definitely won't happen in Utah, Mormons and all. Perhaps the Carolinas would be next on the list, the rest - no chance...hillbilly backwaters and rednecks.

https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/us/equal-rights-amendment-here-are-the-13-states-that-havent-voted-to-ratify-it/ar-AAy5cU6 The Illinois legislature just voted to ratify the ERA. Technically, the last deadline to ratify the ERA passed in 1982. However, Congress has the power to vote to simply extend the deadline if 38 states end up approving it. So, once the ERA gets one more state's blessing, there may be more legislative red tape to get through before it reaches official amendment status. Here are the states that have not voted to ratify the amendment: Alabama
Arizona
Arkansas
Florida
Georgia
Louisiana
Mississippi
Missouri
North Carolina
Oklahoma
South Carolina
Utah
Virginia
Despite a vigorous effort by women's rights advocates, a push to pass the ERA in Virginia died in the state legislature in February. Similar efforts also failed this year in Arizona and Florida.

Wow. That was unexpected. I still don't know if Virginia will do it in the next month. That said, Florida is becoming a bit more blue in recent months. Or maybe locals are becoming more anti-Trump. Combined with the #MeToo movement, it's possible, but still unlikely.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-illinois-era/illinois-passes-equal-rights-amendment-more-than-three-decades-after-deadline-idUSKCN1IW0LB
Illinois joins the party.  The rest of the holdouts continue to seem only dimly likely.  Up from zero, but not much, on this news.

Illinois:  Still needs to pass a reluctant house.
No other states are actively considering
Following up for passage of time.

It sounds like there's a decent chance that Illinois may pass it, but that will be insufficient for a positive resolution of this question in this time-frame.  I don't see any significant action occurring in other states that haven't passed it. http://www.chicagotribune.com/suburbs/naperville-sun/news/ct-nvs-era-rally-house-st-0504-story.html
Free bus rides to Springfield for ERA rally will leave from Naperville

https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/19/opinion/a-rebuke-to-trump-a-century-in-the-making.html The fight centers on Illinois, where the State Senate recently passed a bill to ratify the E.R.A. If the State House of Representatives also passes the legislation — supporters hope to see a vote next month, and are cautiously optimistic about the outcome — then Illinois will become the 37th state to ratify the amendment. Approval by just one more state would bring the measure to the three-quarters threshold required for constitutional amendments. There are a handful of good possibilities, including Florida, Virginia and Utah.
. . . 
There are some questions about what will happen if a 38th state ratifies the amendment, given that it would miss the deadline Congress set by at least 36 years, and five states have even voted to rescind their ratifications. But E.R.A. supporters and some legal experts make a plausible case that the amendment should still be recognized, pointing to, among other things, the 27th Amendment, on congressional pay, which was ratified more than 200 years after its passage by Congress, although no deadline had been set.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Time is running out on this question.  VA has killed it for this year.  I'm not seeing passage in FL or UT, either.  So, this year will be maybe 1 more state:  IL.

http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/politics/ct-met-illinois-equal-rights-amendment-20180411-story.html "The [ERA] amendment passed on a vote of 43-12, with no debate on the Senate floor. It now heads to the House, where sponsoring Rep. Lou Lang, D-Skokie, says he is working to build support but warned it’s far from a “slam-dunk.” The House and Senate each have voted in favor in the past, but it has yet to clear both in the same year. " . . . about 36 years after the amendment appeared to die after just 35 states ratified it, three short of what was needed by the 1982 deadline. That means Illinois’ approval could be largely symbolic. Still, advocates have pushed for a “three-state solution,” contending Congress can extend the deadline and the amendment should go into effect if three additional states vote in favor.
~~~~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  So, it's half way through the process in Illinois, been killed in AZ & VA, and not on the radar (as far as I know) anywhere else.  If it passes the IL House, it'll still have to pass a 2nd state legislature before 7/1 for this question to resolve as yes.
The passage of the ERA REQUIRES public pressure on the legislature. The pressure simply isn't there.
1 July is a tough deadline and 2 states likely won't ratify by then. But Virginia might, so the risk of another domino falling is high.
They would have done it by now
With Va in the no, it has the chances of a lightning strike.
Still has a chance in FL, but don't know where #2 would come from...
If it happens, it will probably be with VA and FL.
Of the States remaining only one might ratify in this time frame.
At least five other states are also looking at it.
Women are becoming more prominent in both being elected and part of the voters themselves.  Another factor is Me Movement.

Va. lawmakers strike down federal Equal Rights Amendment bills
https://wtop.com/virginia/2018/02/va-lawmakers-strike-down-federal-equal-rights-amendment-bills/
The States that have not yet ratified are the centers of the present Trump movement.
A tectonic shift in public support has already begun pushing in the direction of this being the norm.

Republican leaders in the House of Delegates are refusing to hold a hearing on any of three nearly identical bills, which have bipartisan support, dimming their chances this session. 
https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/virginia-politics/gop-house-leaders-in-va-refuse-hearing-on-federal-equal-rights-amendment/2018/02/08/b3c07b02-0ce0-11e8-8b0d-891602206fb7_story.html?utm_term=.0d53d874166f The question of why women continue to support the Republican party remains unanswered.
Women already have equal rights, pretending otherwise is delusional.

I find it increasingly hard to believe that legislators who support the Equal rights Amendment in any of the moderate, deeply divided, or largely conservative states will push to run shit through, waiting as it has been for decades for ratification, so near to hotly contested and nationally significant midterm elections.  There would have to be something pretty significant to rouse even 1 state to bring it up and get votes to pass it right now.

Illinois might ratify ERA this time, which will leave only 1 state left to fall. Senate
      Democratic: 37
      Republican: 22 House   Democratic:	67
  Republican: 	51
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illinois_General_Assembly Democratic House Speaker Michael Madigan picked up enough House Republicans to override Rauner's veto of an income-tax increase last summer to fuel an end to the impasse. 
http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/illinois-gop-governor-urges-unity-ahead-divisive-election-52751711 Though both Illinois houses have passed ERA by a majority vote, the state requires a three-fifths supermajority to ratify the amendment. 
https://www.journal-topics.com/articles/moylan-to-back-era-ratification/

IMHO, IL and VA are the only states with a chance of passing the ERA. Illinois has a bill to pass the  ERA still active: http://www.ilga.gov/legislation/billstatus.asp?DocNum=4&GAID=14&GA=100&DocTypeID=SJRCA&LegID=99262&SessionID=91 Also Virginia: https://docs.wixstatic.com/ugd/20a2e4_9d9899b28807471d994a1edacbb04501.pdf Full list of unratified states and links to their ERA legislation. I'm at just 3% because I get the impression that ERA supporters are tilting at windmills. By introducing legislation, politicians show their voters that they are trying, honest. But I don't see the sort of activity that turns a bill into a ratification.
Equal Rights in the US is white and rich.  So nope.

I like to hope. But of the states failing to ratify, you have a bunch of far-right zealots, evangelicals and Republicans in control. So, no. The only shot is AZ and IL and those are not blue enough yet.
It's not likely but with MeToo, it is possible.
Only one state has taken action in 40 years; of those states that have yet to ratify it, all but one are Republican leaning and republicans are much less likely to make a move.
I do not see enough of an effort being made anywhere to generate sufficient momentum for this.
It's plausible in VA & IL, but appears to only have traction in VA currently.
Not with a GOP lead congress.
Won't happen in the time frame.
Looking at the states listed, I'd say the state legislators will be tied up negotiating a lowering of the age of consent.
states left are either politically conservative or divided.
I don’t hear much about this. There are other issues getting more piece of mind.

http://www.richmond.com/news/local/central-virginia/powhatan/powhatan-today/local-powhatan-girls-involved-in-equal-rights-amendment/article_07ef203e-fb9d-11e7-a0b9-ff975530f870.html

. . ..In the last several years, the Equal Rights Amendment has been passed by the Senate of Virginia five times but killed in the House of Delegates on crossover, . . .  We move the ball a little bit further down the field every year, but we need to hit the goal and be done with this,” . . ..Going into the General Assembly’s 60-day session, these local groups are once again lobbying to see the constitutional amendment ratified in both the Senate and House of Delegates.

. . . . [the Weber's] traveled to New York City for . . .  [Eastan's] milestone 10th birthday last June, and while there, they made plans to take a picture of her standing next to the Fearless Girl statue that was still installed on Wall Street. The 4-foot bronze statue of a little girl . . . stood opposite the iconic Charging Bull sculpture and represented the need for gender equality. “I loved it [the photo] because she was my kid, but neither one of us were prepared for how other people reacted to it. It is almost like she became this little living mascot for women’s rights or girl’s rights or just fairness in women’s futures because that was the basis of that statute,” .

“I was horrified to find out that it is OK to pay me less than a boy even though I work as hard as him, am as smart as him and am better for the job,” Eastan said. “At first when my mom told me the ERA wasn’t passed in Virginia but it was in other states I was confused because I thought we had equal rights already, and then in comes pow, in your face that we don’t.”

When the Women-Matter group asked to use Eastan’s photo for this purpose, the Webers agreed. Weber said they received permission from the statue’s artist to use the image in marketing materials but not State Street Corporation, which commissioned it, so it was removed from their marketing materials and what was left was her daughter standing proud.

The advocacy of a new generation, “you could feel it in that photograph,” . . . . She saw the photo as showing that the message of the need for the ERA had reached a new generation and that “their advocacy is the blood transfusion we needed.”

The image is on an electronic billboard near where I-95 and I-64 meet so it could greet legislators in the General Assembly as they arrived in Richmond for the new session this month, she said.

All of the attention has surprised Eastan, who struggled to wrap her head around why her picture would be such a prominent part of the fight for women’s equality, her mom said.

“She really feels there are all of these older ladies who have been working on this issue for so many years. Why is she getting this attention?” Weber said. “I said part of what her contribution is is she has a genuine and authentic belief in this subject.”

On the same billboard that displays Eastan’s image is a slogan made special by Ani Hornung, a 12-year-old homeschooled Powhatan student and the daughter of Kati and Andrew Hornung.

The simple phrase “Not One More GenERAtion” highlights the need for the Equal Rights Amendment to be passed so another generation of girls doesn’t have to experience the same kind of discrimination as those who came before, said Kati Hornung. Hornung learned that the ERA had not been ratified in Virginia several years ago but didn’t really start getting involved until last year.

. . . “I was upset; I think it should have passed awhile ago,” Ani said. “I want to see the ERA passed very, very badly.” So they made some homemade signs, and on one where her mom had written “Not one more generation,” Ani noticed ERA was in the word generation and colored them red and underlined them.

Davis was at that rally in front of the General Assembly and remembers seeing Ani’s homemade sign and her emphasis on the ERA in generation. “I looked at that sign and I said ‘My God it has been staring at us in the face all the time,’ ” she said. “The reflection of the new generation is looking at it and saying how long has this been going on? My generation is going to take care of it. She has just caught it. It came from a 12-year-old Powhatan kid, a phrase that is taking off nationally.”

The involvement of the girls and young women is a good sign of more people learning about the Equal Rights Amendment simply because many people erroneously believe it already passed, Davis said. She said that far too many women don’t even know this is still an issue others are fighting for on their behalf.

Proponents of the amendment also face arguments that the ERA is not needed anymore because the rights of women are already protected under laws such as the Pregnancy Discrimination Act, Equal Pay Act and Violence Against Women Act.
 Women’s groups such as Women-Matter argue those are all laws that can be altered or repealed and have no constitutional standing. Davis cites the words of the late Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia, who was interviewed by California Lawyer in a January 2011 issue and said, "Certainly the Constitution does not require discrimination on the basis of sex. The only issue is whether it prohibits it. It doesn't."

. . . “I think there is a lot of misinformation about this issue. I also think when you are used to privilege, equality feels like oppression. I feel there are a lot of people who feel that to give equality to everyone, those who enjoy privilege have to give something up,”. . .  Equality is like love; the more you give the more you have.” . . . Senators and delegates were invited on Monday, Jan. 16 to a screening of the documentary “Equal Means Equal” at the Byrd Theatre in Richmond. Supporters of the amendment will also continue to lobby on behalf of ratification during the 60-day session and especially focus on getting it out of subcommittee in the House of Delegates, Davis added.

“We want the dignity of the debate. We deserve to have this long overdue conversation on the floor of both chambers with debate and with a registered vote,” she said. “It is time that every delegate in the state of Virginia is accountable to their position on this issue.”
~~~~~~~
http://www.peoplesworld.org/article/virginia-general-assembly-starts-2018-session-with-push-for-progressive-laws/ On Wednesday, January 10, the House of Delegates, the lower house of the Virginia General Assembly started off its new sixty-day session with a sharply altered balance of power. Despite recounts and disputes, the legislature has ended up with a razor-thin Republican majority. Democrats in the body are not letting that stop them from pursuing a broad agenda of progressive reforms, however. In the November elections, Democratic Party candidates, most of them solidly progressive, flipped fifteen formerly Republican seats. The Democrats came within two seats of achieving a majority in the House of Delegates, for the first time in 18 years. Going into the election, the House was split 66 Republicans to 34 Democrats, but an increase in voter turnout in the Democratic Party’s social base produced a major transformation. In Northern Virginia and other areas, progressive grassroots action brought into office a whole new contingent of young delegates, many of them minorities and/or women, plus the first transgender woman ever to be elected (Danica Roem). The Democrats just missed getting an actual one vote majority. In the 94th legislative district in Southeastern Virginia, a tied election was decided by the drawing of a name from a bowl, which produced the re-election of Republican incumbent David Yancey (the defeated Democrat, Shelly Simonds, could have asked for another recount, but decided not to). In the 28th legislative district, centered on the Northern Virginia city of Fredericksburg, the Republican candidate, Robert Thomas, defeated Democrat Joshua Cole by few votes in an election marred by an error by the local election authorities, who assigned numerous voters from Democrat-strong areas to a neighboring district by mistake. Democratic voters took this result to federal court, but the judge declined to intervene, and an appeal did not prosper either. So, for now, the House of Delegates stays at 51 Republicans and 49 Democrats. The Virginia Senate, not up for election last year or this, also has a very narrow Republican majority of 21 Republicans to 19 Democrats. In last year’s election, Democrats won all three of the state’s elective executive offices. The new Democratic governor, Ralph Northam, was sworn in on January 13. The Democrats and the progressive grassroots organizations whose efforts made their advances possible are not discouraged by falling just short of a legislative majority. After all, in the election to the House of Delegates last year, the Democrats won a total of 53.17 percent of the vote, and the Republicans only 43.76 percent. The Democrats and the grassroots activists argue that, were it not for racially-influenced gerrymandering of districts by Republican-controlled legislatures in recent years, there would be a Democratic majority in both houses by now. And then there is the matter of vote suppression, including measures such as the difficulty of restoring voting rights to felons, and onerous voter ID regulations, to name just the two most prominent complaints. True, the slim Republican majority has allowed that party to choose the leadership of both houses and their committees, which is no small matter. But the fact that such a large change was brought about by a mobilized activist base and a resulting increase in voter turnout is demoralizing for the Republicans and very encouraging for the Democrats and the people who voted for them. Both Democrats and Republicans have noticed that the Democratic surge in 2017 could be a harbinger of a similar change in 2018. So the Democrats are motivated and energized, and the grassroots even more so. In equal measure, the Republicans appear demoralized. Perhaps it is not surprising, then, that the amazing number of bills already introduced in the new session of the General Assembly so far don’t include the same quantum of extreme reactionary, misogynistic, homophobic, and other backward nonsense that have been Virginia Republicans’ stock in trade in recent years. [Do you think we might be reading a Democrat-leaning source here??? Anne] On the other hand, a large number of progressive bills have been introduced by Democratic senators and delegates, including especially the newly elected ones. These measures will, in most cases, not only receive the support of all or almost all the Democratic senators and delegates, they are also likely to be supported by Gov. Northam. Moreover, they will have very active support from the same grassroots forces that made the change in the composition of the legislature possible. So the mere fact there is a razor-thin Republican majority is not going to discourage either the Democrats or the activists. . ..  On the women’s rights front, HJ 2 would sign Virginia onto the Equal Rights Amendment, correcting an old disgrace for this state.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  this is an important issue for me, so I may be making more of these reports than is merited, however, it appears to me that a significant--larger than ever--campaign for passage of the ERA in Virginia is gaining momentum and that there's a greater chance for its passage due to changes in the legislature. If passage in only 1 state was required, my forecast would be 50%+, but this question asks for two, and I haven't gotten the sense that the issue is gaining momentum in any other state.
The states so inclined, already have. Some states have tried to retract their positive votes in favor.
Time seems to be running out.  Virginia House of Delegates coin flip made things harder as Republicans won.  Despite #METOO, urgency not there.
Topic not in MSNBC, which is liberal-leaning.  Maybe IL will come on board, but without civilians pushing this, which isn't occurring much, it won't happen.
I think the problem is timing.

http://wtvr.com/2018/01/15/womens-rights-groups-urge-virginia-to-ratify-era/ Women’s rights groups urge Virginia to ratify ERA
wtvr.com
The fight to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment in Virginia has gained momentum with the national discourse about sexual harassment and gender equity. The fight to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment in Virginia has gained momentum with the national discourse about sexual harassment and gender equity and social media campaigns such as #MeToo and #YesAllWomen. . . . The deadline for the ERA ratification expired decades ago, but . . .  ERA supporters say there’s a legal basis for waiving the deadline. The Nevada Legislature ratified the amendment last year, and groups like Women Matter hope Virginia will follow suit.

. . . The resolutions argue that there is no legal basis for putting time limits on ratifying a constitutional amendment. ERA supporters note that the so-called Madison Amendment, relating to compensation of members of Congress, was proposed by our first U.S. Congress and wasn’t ratified until 203 years later.

Surovell also proposed a resolution to ratify the ERA last year. It was killed in the Senate Rules Committee. His legislative aide, Philip Scranage, said Surovell is sure the amendment has a better chance this time around. His optimism stems partly from the election of 12 additional women to the Virginia House of Delegates. Several women’s rights advocacy groups are pushing the General Assembly to ratify the ERA. They include the National Organization for Women, Women Matter and the American Association of University Women. Such groups say the ERA must be ratified because equal rights are important for all and should not discriminate based on gender.

. . . The AAUW and other groups are sponsoring a showing of a film . . .  about gender discrimination and its impact on American society. The film, “Equal Means Equal,” is a documentary directed by Kamala Lopez . . . .

“I believe that the addition of a gender equality clause to the United States Constitution is not only the first necessary action to fix the problem, but the ONLY single action that will effectively begin to address what is a systemic and institutional crisis,” Lopez wrote in a message to viewers on the Equal Means Equal website.
~~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  It sounds like there's some momentum building in VA for passage!  but that's only one state . . . .

Florida state lawmakers reintroduce bill to ratify Equal Rights Amendment
http://www.firstcoastnews.com/article/news/local/florida-state-lawmakers-reintroduce-bill-to-ratify-equal-rights-amendment/77-506676912

The nation is moving in this direction.  However, it won't happen until after the 2018 midterms elections when the seats of white male legislators, who are leaving en masse, are filled with a more diverse and female legislative body.  Sexual harrassment reaction is a cultural watershed moment. We are still in "discovery mode"--so far, the focus has been on high profile entertainment and media folks with confidentiality agreements crumbling; not much on the street yet.  Equal pay, desegregated groups and teams, all of this will move forward after 2018
I'm surprised that with all the talk about #metoo and never again, that there isn't more talk about passage of the ERA.
While the blue states like virginia may ratify it by then I doubt the other southern states will follow suit
Seems like they would have voted yes already
It's more of a hope than a certainty.   But the chances are slim, much as I regret that.
States can make more meaningful progress on matters of gender equality in specific cases, such as forbidding salary history disclosures.
FL, VA, AZ, IL most likely states to approve, AR, MS, UT in a dead last heat to NEVER approve ERA.

amendment expired.  a new (even if identical) amendment would have to be passed by congress to get states to ratify it, and congress has many more timely and important issues on its agenda to revert to this.
VA is a possibility given the recent electoral swings it has seen but the others are too far gone in terms of their ideological bent to do this.

Given the list of states yet to ratify the ERA, it can conceivably happen only in IL and VA in the question's timeframe. But the election outcome for House in VA is still in limbo  - so the delegates would have other priorities. May be after the mid-terms...
And with the elimination of the chance of a Dem-controlled VA House, I drop the odds from 1% to 0%.
The ERA is not a focus of the current feminist movement as of Jan 4 2018. If it were, then I would give this a much higher chance of passage, esp in IL and VA.
Given how there isn't much public pressure, it's hard to see how two of the above states would make considerable moves to ratify within six months.
All the states listed are conservative, male dominated states. VA might.

With the current climate of War on Women by the GOP Congress, chance of passing any  Equal Rights Amendment is zero.  However, 2018 will be the year of the Woman as more find their voice and speak truth to power.
If they (incumbent Rs) are afraid of the black and brown voters they'll talk about it. If they will loose without it, there's a slight chance.
No, but it is much more likely to happen in 2019 after the democratic wave in 2018 flips a number of state legislatures to democratic control.
It's about time women get the same rights of a man doing her exact same job! I believe Virginia will be one of the states to ratify but the 2nd state is a toss up for me.
The rise of #metoo, couple with Doug Jones's win could add one state to NV, as a matter of definitional politics in a purple or lean-blue state.

Factoid:  the 27th amendment, regarding Congressional pay was ratified in 1992, 203 years after it was approved by Congress.  Illinois Senator Steans is working to secure enough votes on her side of the aisle for passage in Illinois; she’s a couple short. Steans says some of those who won’t commit have told her that they will get aboard – but not until the March primary election is over and they feel safer announcing their support.
All of the remaining States either have Republican-dominated State Legislatures or the Republicans can prevent the super-majority required for approval.
Today was the first day that bills could be filed for the upcoming 2018 Virginia General Assembly session:  SJ 4 United States Constitution; Equal Rights Amendment.
Not too many forward-looking legislatures in the states listed

It’s #meToo time for the Equal Rights Amendment in the Illinois legislature
https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/its-metoo-time-for-the-equal-rights-amendment-in_us_59fa6359e4b09887ad6f3d4a
http://www.ilga.gov/legislation/BillStatus.asp?DocTypeID=SJRCA&DocNum=4&GAID=14&SessionID=91&LegID=99262 If Illinois ratifies, that leaves only 1 more!
I had thought that NY might vote to convene a convention but they did not, so reducing to 0

A rally is being held in the coming week in Illinois in support of ratification.

History of ratification efforts in Illinois, per Wikipedia:
Senate voted to ratify the ERA in May 1972 with a tally of 30 to 21, 
Senate voted to ratify again on May 22, 2014 (SJRCA No. 75) with a tally of 39 to 11 House voted to ratify on May 1, 1975 with a tally of 113 to 62, 
House voted to ratify May 21, 2003 with a tally of 76 to 41 (HJRCA No. 1).  At various times, votes were conducted in both houses of the Illinois General Assembly on the question of ratifying the ERA and while most members voted in favor of ratification, the result was always less than the three-fifths supermajority vote in each house of the Illinois General Assembly for ratification as required by the internal parliamentary rules of both the Illinois Senate and the Illinois House of Representatives.  A provision of the Illinois State Constitution, which had required a supermajority of three-fifths in both legislative chambers, was found to be unconstitutional by the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois in the 1975 case of Dyer v. Blair. Since then, the ERA has been voted on multiple times, but has only ever passed in one of the chambers. The most recent vote in favor of the ERA was in the state senate in May 2014 with a tally of 39 to 11, and 6 voting present. The DRT "locker room banter" tape last fall infuriated women and triggered them to talk privately to the men in their lives (step 1).  The Weinstein revelations have triggered women to speak PUBLICLY about sexual harassment and assault (step 2).  I think that step 3 will be legislation, including, but not limited to ratification of the ERA.
There is no news of bills involving ERA being tabled.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

http://people.com/movies/lina-esco-swat-harvey-weinstein-sexual-harassment/ Lina " . . . Esco is pushing for gender equality with her launch of the Human Campaign, which seeks to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment in the United States. “We have finally a momentum again with woman after the women’s march. There’s all these momentums happening but if we don’t do something with it, it’s just going to go away. It’s just going to be a trend. Same thing with all these women coming out against Harvey. We have to do something with this. We have to hold these people accountable for what they’re doing and we need to continue speaking up and taking risks,” she said. “Taking risks might mean that we might lose our jobs. But it’s the bigger picture. What we’re doing is creating a ripple effect for other men and women to come out and speak about what’s happening,” Esco said. “And this is the same thing with women’s rights. If we don’t capitalize on this and we keep looking at it as just a trend or something to tweet about or Instagram about, that’s not enough. You need to be active. And that’s what I’m saying — the Equal Rights Amendment, the Human Campaign and what we’re doing. This is not my thing, this is everyone’s thing. It’s important to come together. You can be helping women here and helping  women there. But if we’re not in the Constitution, there’s nothing more important than that. Nothing.”
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  Somebody has to elevate the profile of the ERA and create public pressure for states to pass it, perhaps Esco is the person.  Increasing my forecast!
Only Illinois and Virginia might. The others are fairly or extremely red states.
Considering the states that have not chosen to ratify up to this point I say slim to none.
I think most of the states that have not signed the Amendment are republican held and thus unlikely to ratify the amendment.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
IL and VA might consider it. IL may even ratify. The rest? Ice cubes have more of a chance in Hades.
None of remaining states will stand for their people's wishes.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
I would say Illinois, Arizona, and Virginia are probably the most likely
Updating for the passage of time.
Continuing polarization does not make the wide state support for ratification possible.
None of the remaining states have both a Democrat governor and a Democrat legislature.

The good news we all welcomed is that a coalition of women’s groups: AAUW (American Association of University Women), League of Women Voters, Business and Professional Women and National Organization of Women are joining in the effort to have Arizona legislators ratify the Equal Rights Amendment.
http://www.gvnews.com/opinion/era-efforts/article_3ef441a0-a31d-11e7-9018-2f7d04fa1083.html One state looks likely, but no news of a second.
Not very likely in current political environment.
Don´t see that happening for two states.
We saw legalizing same sex marriage in many countries, including the US, in the past few years. ERA will happen.

Of any minority group in the US, the LGBT community has achieved the most progress in the past decade.  Same sex marriage was publicly and comfortably opposed by conservative candidates.  Religious groups vehemently denounced same sex marriage.  Then one day, without much protest, same sex marriage became federally legal and widely accepted.  Gender issues are confusing to most people currently, and passing the Equal Rights Amendment may be a function of the passing of the old guard within state legislatures.  In my opinion, the best strategic option to pass the Equal Rights Amendment is for candidates in favor of the Constitution Amendment to slowly gain seats in state legislatures, then join together and ratify the Amendment.  It's an old issue, timing is the problem and I believe the Equal Rights Amendment will fail to be ratified by 38 states on or before July 1, 2018.
Deeply divided legislatures in many states.

The Equal Rights Amendment was passed by Congress on March 22, 1972 and sent to the states for ratification. In order to be added to the Constitution, it needed approval by legislatures in three-fourths (38) of the 50 states. On March 22, 2017, 45 years to the day after Congress passed the ERA, Nevada became the 36th state to ratify it.  In 2017 ERA bills have also been introduced in the legislatures of Arizona, Florida, Illinois, North Carolina, Utah, and Virginia.
http://www.equalrightsamendment.org/states.htm
http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/21/520962541/nevada-on-cusp-of-ratifying-equal-rights-amendment-35-years-after-deadline Given that 6 legislatures have the relevant legislation as bills, and only 2 need to approve, the odds are strongly in favour.

I identified four states as potential ratifiers: Arizona, Illinois, Louisiana, and Virginia. I assume every Democrat in the state legislature would vote to approve and 15% of Republicans would do so. Such an assumption means that the amendment passes through at least one house for each of those states. Concentrated efforts in Illinois, as well as an election year in Virginia which I suspect will shift power towards Democrats, make ratification in these states more likely. However, Republican controlled legislatures make it less likely that ratification is ever put to a vote as leadership would protect members from potentially embarrassing no votes. Overall, I think it is likely for Illinois to pass the ERA in the next year given its renewed energy. Virginia has a 50/50 shot in my opinion of passing the ERA. The potential of being the last state necessary to ratify the amendment might be enough to push Virginia over the edge, so I'll lean slightly towards Virginia passing it. Let's say 75% chance that Illinois passes, 55% chance that Virginia passes, and below 50% for Arizona or Louisiana. The question is if 2 will pass though, so Illinois isn't as important here. What are the chances that Virginia, Arizona, or Louisiana will pass this thing? Probably around 50%. I'm reducing my answer to 45% to account for the potential that Illinois doesn't pass it though.

Illinois and Virginia are the two states most likely to ratify. The House in the Illinois General Assembly would require three Republican votes to ratify the amendment and it's unlikely to pass the House of Delegates in Virginia. There is not much pressure to ratify because most voters assume the constitution already grants equal rights and it's legally unclear whether the amendment can be passed after the deadline. There seems to low awareness of this issue even after Nevada made a splash by ratifying it (the issue peaked on Google Trends in 2013). Plus, it's extremely rare that a constitutional amendment is ever ratified.  If Illinois were to ratify the amendment, only one more state would be needed to ratify the amendment. If that were to happen and control of the Virginia legislature were to switch to Democrats in the November 2017 elections, then the probability would increase substantially.

Let's see, looking at all the non-ratifying states that voted Democrat in any of the last five Presidential elections . . . Illinois Senate has passed, it needs 70 votes in the House, and has 67 Democrats.  There's a decent but not overwhelming chance of passage if the rules allow it, which is disputed. Virginia's Senate has passed, but the House is 66% Republican, and every recent attempt to pass the ERA there (2011, 2012, 2014, 2015) has failed. Florida has a 60% Republican Senate and a 65% Republican House, and while an ERA bill has been submitted to committee, the committee took no action on it. North Carolina's Senate is 70% Republican and its House is 62%. Arizona, while not meeting the any-of-last-five criterion, is swingy enough that it has to be considered, I guess.  It just quashed the latest attempt back at the end of April, and it has solid Republican majorities in state House and Senate. And while "momentum" is usually a good thing, causing the inevitable legal mess that would result (the deadline, the extended deadline, the four states that declared they rescinded their ratifications, the state that declared afterward its ratification was contingent on the original deadline) might convince legislators that they don't want to actually pass it if they're the state that would open that can of worms.
This would be a cause worthy of Michele Obama, Hillary Clinton, Elizabeth Warren, Dianne Feinstein and others.

Not a promising list.  Virginia and Illinois are Maybes from a political standpoint, but not overwhelmingly likely in either case. According to Article XIV, Section 4, of the Illinois Constitution, "The affirmative vote of three-fifths of the members elected to each house of the General Assembly shall be required to , , , ratify a proposed amendment to the Constitution of the United States. . . .The General Assembly shall not take action on any proposed amendment to the Constitution of the United States . . .  unless a majority of the members of the General Assembly shall have been elected after the proposed amendment has been submitted for ratification."  There being no way this can happen before next summer, Illinois is out, even if they could muster the votes (and it's a high standard--3/5 of the membership, not just present-and-voting).
http://www.ilga.gov/commission/lrb/con14.htm If Virginia has anything in its constitution about how to do this, I can't find it.  Must be in statute someplace.  Other states, I suspect, require extraordinary majorities for This Sort Of Thing.  Anyway, if Illinois can't meet this deadline and nobody else on that iist wants to, Virginia doesn't matter.  If anything strange happens, this number will have to go up, of course.  (Well, not just anything strange--that's already taken care of--I mean anything unexpected on this front.) Meantime, if you're ever questioned by the police, plead the Third Amendment:  "I refuse to answer on the grounds that soldiers may be quartered in my house during peacetime without my consent."

Assessing at 15% to begin with, one percentage point per month remaining in the period.  While Nevada has sparked the revival of this, the list of remaining states is not favorable to getting two more states. NV has Democratic controlled Senate and Assemblies. The best bets would be IL and VA. With a governor's election in VA in November, it will be worth watching to see if this gets traction as an election issue. Currently, the VA General Assembly is controlled by Republicans in both houses, so ratification would not be likely unless Democrats won a landslide in the House elections. IL has a more favorable General Assembly, and discussions are beginning about ratification, so it's more likely they might ratify in the time frame provided. Of the remaining states, they are all solidly controlled by Republicans, which decreases the likelihood of any of them ratifying the amendment, especially since a number of those states have enacted voter restrictive legislation over the past couple years. Seems to me they probably would not be keen on equal rights in that case.
